natural problem: The function $f$ is linear and satisfies $f(d+1)-f(d) = 3$ for all real numbers $d$. What is $f(3)-f(5)$?
natural solution: Taking $d = 3,$ we get \[f(4) - f(3) = 3.\]Taking $d = 4,$ we get \[f(5) - f(4) = 3.\]Adding these equations, we get $f(5) - f(3) = 6,$ so $f(3) - f(5) = \boxed{-6}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>d. f (d + 1) - f d = 3"
shows  "f 3 - f 5 = -6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function $f$ is linear and satisfies $f(d+1)-f(d) = 3$ for all real numbers $d$. What is $f(3)-f(5)$? The final Answer is -6
 ### Proof
 Taking $d = 3,$ we get \[f(4) - f(3) = 3.\]Taking $d = 4,$ we get \[f(5) - f(4) = 3.\]Adding these equations, we get $f(5) - f(3) = 6,$ so $f(3) - f(5) = \boxed{-6}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>d. f (d + 1) - f d = 3"
shows  "f 3 - f 5 = -6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If the difference between the value of a function at any real number $d$ and the value of the function at $d+1$ is always $3$, what is the difference between the value of the function at $3$ and the value at $5$? The final answer is $-6$.

 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>d. f(d + 1) - f d = 3"
shows  "f 3 - f 5 = -6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If a function $f$ has the property that the difference between its value at any real number and its value at the next consecutive real number is always 3, what is the difference between $f(3)$ and $f(5)$? The final answer is $-6$.
